natural problem: If two distinct numbers are selected at random from the first seven prime numbers, what is the probability that their sum is an even number? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: The only way for the sum to not be even is if one of the primes chosen is 2. There are six pairs where one of the primes is 2, and there are $\binom{7}{2}=21$ total possible pairs, so the probability that the sum is NOT even is $\frac{6}{21}=\frac{2}{7}$.
Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p1 p2 :: nat
assumes h0 : "set [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "p1 \<in> primes"
and h2 : "p2 \<in> primes"
and h3 : "p1 \<noteq> p2"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> primes \<and> (\<exists> y. y \<in> primes \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> (x + y) mod 2 = 0)} = 5"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If two distinct numbers are selected at random from the first seven prime numbers, what is the probability that their sum is an even number? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{7}
 ### Proof
 The only way for the sum to not be even is if one of the primes chosen is 2. There are six pairs where one of the primes is 2, and there are $\binom{7}{2}=21$ total possible pairs, so the probability that the sum is NOT even is $\frac{6}{21}=\frac{2}{7}$.
 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p1 p2 :: nat
assumes h0 : "set [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "p1 \<in> primes"
and h2 : "p2 \<in> primes"
and h3 : "p1 \<noteq> p2"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> primes \<and> (\<exists> y. y \<in> primes \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> (x + y) mod 2 = 0)} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many distinct pairs of prime numbers have an even sum, given the set of prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}? The final answer is 5.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_even :: "real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "P_even = (\<lambda>x. even (nat x))"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<longrightarrow> is_prime x"
and h2 : "distinct [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
shows  "P (\<lambda>(x, y). x \<noteq> y \<and> h0 (x + y)) (set_of_primes 2 17) = 5 / 7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If two distinct numbers are selected at random from the first seven prime numbers, what is the probability that their sum is an even number? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{7}
 ### Proof
 The only way for the sum to not be even is if one of the primes chosen is 2. There are six pairs where one of the primes is 2, and there are $\binom{7}{2}=21$ total possible pairs, so the probability that the sum is NOT even is $\frac{6}{21}=\frac{2}{7}$.
 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P_even :: "real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "P_even = (\<lambda>x. even (nat x))"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<longrightarrow> is_prime x"
and h2 : "distinct [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
shows  "P (\<lambda>(x, y). x \<noteq> y \<and> h0 (x + y)) (set_of_primes 2 17) = 5 / 7"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider the set of prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}. Find the probability that the sum of any two distinct primes from this set is an even number. The final answer is $\frac{5}{7}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and P_even_sum :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "distinct A"
and h2 : "P_even_sum = real (card {p + q | p q. p \<in> A \<and> q \<in> A \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> even (p + q)}) / real (card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> A \<and> q \<in> A \<and> p \<noteq> q})"
shows  "P_even_sum = 5 / 7"
a_2.formal solution:

 ### Proof

 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "int set" and P_even_sum :: "real"
assumes h0 : "A = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "distinct A"
and h2 : "P_even_sum = real (card {p + q | p q. p \<in> A \<and> q \<in> A \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> even (p + q)}) / real (card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> A \<and> q \<in> A \<and> p \<noteq> q})"
shows  "P_even_sum = 5 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider the set of prime numbers A = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}. Find the probability that the sum of any two distinct elements from the set is even. The final answer is $\frac{5}{7}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum>x\<in>{2,3,5,7,11,13,17}. \<Sum>y\<in>{2,3,5,7,11,13,17}. if x \<noteq> y \<and> even (x + y) then 1 else 0) / (\<Sum>x\<in>{2,3,5,7,11,13,17}. \<Sum>y\<in>{2,3,5,7,11,13,17}. if x \<noteq> y then 1 else 0)"
shows  "prob = 5 / 7"

 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

fixes prob :: "real"

shows  "prob = 5 / 7"

a_3.informal problem: In a set containing prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}, what is the probability that the sum of two distinct primes from this set is an even number? The final answer is $\frac{5}{7}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> bool" and even_sum :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "distinct [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. even_sum x y \<longleftrightarrow> (x \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> y \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> even (x + y))"
and h2 : "P x \<longleftrightarrow> even_sum x y"
and h3 : "card {x. P x} = 5"
shows  "card {x. P x} / card {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} = 5 / 7"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If two distinct numbers are selected at random from the first seven prime numbers, what is the probability that their sum is an even number? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{7}
 ### Proof
 The only way for the sum to not be even is if one of the primes chosen is 2. There are six pairs where one of the primes is 2, and there are $\binom{7}{2}=21$ total possible pairs, so the probability that the sum is NOT even is $\frac{6}{21}=\frac{2}{7}$.
 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> bool" and even_sum :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "distinct [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17]"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. even_sum x y \<longleftrightarrow> (x \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> y \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> even (x + y))"
and h2 : "P x \<longleftrightarrow> even_sum x y"
and h3 : "card {x. P x} = 5"
shows  "card {x. P x} / card {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} = 5 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given the distinct prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}, consider a property P(x) that is true if and only if there exists a number y such that both x and y are in the given set, x is not equal to y, and their sum is even. If there are 5 numbers that satisfy this property P(x), find the ratio of the count of numbers that satisfy P(x) to the count of the given prime numbers. The final answer is $\frac{5}{7}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p1 p2 :: nat and primes :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "primes = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "p1 \<in> primes"
and h2 : "p2 \<in> primes"
and h3 : "p1 \<noteq> p2"
shows  "probability_even_sum p1 p2 = 5 / 7"

 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and P :: "rat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} \<longrightarrow> p n \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> prime (p n)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} \<and> n \<noteq> 1 \<longrightarrow> q n \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> prime (q n)"
and h2 : "even (p 1 + q 1)"
and h3 : "P x = (\<forall>n. n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} \<and> n \<noteq> 1 \<longrightarrow> even (p n + q n))"
shows  "x = 5 / 7"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If two distinct numbers are selected at random from the first seven prime numbers, what is the probability that their sum is an even number? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{7}
 ### Proof
 The only way for the sum to not be even is if one of the primes chosen is 2. There are six pairs where one of the primes is 2, and there are $\binom{7}{2}=21$ total possible pairs, so the probability that the sum is NOT even is $\frac{6}{21}=\frac{2}{7}$.
 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and P :: "rat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} \<longrightarrow> p n \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> prime (p n)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} \<and> n \<noteq> 1 \<longrightarrow> q n \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> prime (q n)"
and h2 : "even (p 1 + q 1)"
and h3 : "P x = (\<forall>n. n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} \<and> n \<noteq> 1 \<longrightarrow> even (p n + q n))"
shows  "x = 5 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider two sequences of prime numbers, $p_n$ and $q_n$, where $n$ ranges from 1 to 7. The primes in these sequences are drawn from the set {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}. Both sequences share the property that, for any $n \neq 1$, the sum $p_n + q_n$ is even. Additionally, the sum $p_1 + q_1$ is also even. Find the value of the ratio $\frac{p_5}{q_7}$. The final answer is $\frac{5}{7}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "a \<in> S"
and h2 : "b \<in> S"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h4 : "even (a + b)"
shows  "card {x \<in> S. even (\<Sum>y\<in>{a, b}. y)} = 5"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If two distinct numbers are selected at random from the first seven prime numbers, what is the probability that their sum is an even number? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{5}{7}
 ### Proof
 The only way for the sum to not be even is if one of the primes chosen is 2. There are six pairs where one of the primes is 2, and there are $\binom{7}{2}=21$ total possible pairs, so the probability that the sum is NOT even is $\frac{6}{21}=\frac{2}{7}$.
 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat and S :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "S = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "a \<in> S"
and h2 : "b \<in> S"
and h3 : "a \<noteq> b"
and h4 : "even (a + b)"
shows  "card {x \<in> S. even (\<Sum>y\<in>{a, b}. y)} = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Let $S = \{2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17\}$ be a set of distinct prime numbers. If $a$ and $b$ are two different elements of $S$, and the sum of $a$ and $b$ is even, how many pairs $(a, b)$ satisfy these conditions? The final answer is 5.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p1 p2 :: nat and primes :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "primes = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "p1 \<in> primes"
and h2 : "p2 \<in> primes"
and h3 : "p1 \<noteq> p2"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>(p1, p2). p1 + p2 mod 2 = 0) {(p1, p2). p1 \<in> primes \<and> p2 \<in> primes \<and> p1 \<noteq> p2} = 5 / 7"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p1 p2 :: nat and primes :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "primes = {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}"
and h1 : "p1 \<in> primes"
and h2 : "p2 \<in> primes"
and h3 : "p1 \<noteq> p2"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>(p1, p2). p1 + p2 mod 2 = 0) {(p1, p2). p1 \<in> primes \<and> p2 \<in> primes \<and> p1 \<noteq> p2} = 5 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider the set of prime numbers $primes = \{2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17\}$. If you randomly select two distinct prime numbers $p1$ and $p2$ from this set, what is the probability that their sum is an even number? The final answer is $\frac{5}{7}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "rat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "prob x = (x = 5 / 7)"
shows  "prob (card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> q \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> even (p + q)} / card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> q \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> p \<noteq> q})"
a_9.formal solution:

 ### Proof

 Therefore, the probability that the sum IS even is $1-\frac{2}{7}=\boxed{\frac{5}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "rat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "prob x = (x = 5 / 7)"
shows  "prob (card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> q \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> even (p + q)} / card {(p, q) | p q. p \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> q \<in> {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17} \<and> p \<noteq> q})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a set of distinct prime numbers {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17}, what is the probability that the sum of any two distinct prime numbers is even? The final answer is $\frac{5}{7}$.
